children.name: buy a1
children.definition: buy/baɪ/  to pay money for something so that you can own it:
examples: ▪ i bought a new dress today at macy’s.
▪ john makes his living buying and selling used cars.
▪ the painting was bought by a museum in new york.
buy somebody something
▪ keith was going to buy me a ring, but now he says he wants to buy me a watch instead.
buy something for somebody
▪ if you don’t have enough money for the pen, i’ll buy it for you.
buy something from somebody
▪ i wouldn’t buy anything from him - i don’t trust him.
buy something for $10/£200 etc
▪ the ranch, which was originally bought for $20,000, is now valued at over $2 million.
buyverbbought,boughtpay for mua
[ i or t ] to get something by paying money for it
_ [ + two objects ]he bought his mother some flowers /he bought some flowersforhis mother.
_i bought my camerafrom/informaloffa friend of mine.

children.name: get a1
children.definition: get/get/  especiallyspokento buy something, especiallyordinarythings such as food, clothes, or thingsfor your house:
examples: ▪ let me get the drinks. it’s my turn to pay.
▪ did you remember to get the bread?
get somebody something
▪ guess what he got her for her birthday - an iron!
get something for somebody
▪ i’m going to get one of those video games for hillary.
get something for £20/$50 etc
▪ what do you think of this leather jacket? i got it for $40 on sale.

children.name: purchase b2
children.definition: purchase/ˈpɜːʳtʃɪs, ˈpɜːʳtʃəs/  formal to buy something- used in business and legal contracts:
examples: ▪ foreign investors are not permitted to purchase land.
▪ if this product does not give complete satisfaction, please return it to the manufacturer stating when and where it was purchased.
purchase[uncountable noun]purchase of
▪ the loan was supposed to be used for the purchase of a house.
purchase st with st
▪ she perchased her first house with the money
purchaseverb[ t ]formal mua, tậu
to buy
she purchased her first housewiththe money. bằngtiền

children.name: snap up x
children.definition: snap up/ˌsnæp ˈʌp/  to buy somethingimmediately, especially because it is verycheapor youwantit very much, and you are worried that someone else might buy it first:
examples: chộp lấy
snap up something
▪ readers have snapped up nearly 200,000 copies of the book.
▪ the best bargains tend to be snapped up immediately.
snap something up
▪ if you see one for under $100, snap it up!

children.name: splash out on sth x
children.definition: splash out onbritish splurge (on something)american  /ˌsplæʃ ˈaʊt ɒn, ˈsplɜːʳdʒ ɒn/ to buy something you want such as anexpensivemeal, dress etc, which you would not usually buy because it is too expensive:
examples: phung phí tiền ...
▪ we splashed out on a bottle of champagne to celebrate her promotion.
▪ let’s splurge and have the steak.

children.name: pick up x
children.definition: pick up/ˌpɪk ˈʌp/  to buy something that you have foundby chance, especially something that is unusuallycheap:
examples: kiếm được
pick up something
▪ he’s hoping to pick up a few bargains at the sales.
▪ it’s just a little thing i picked up when i was in kathmandu.
pick something up
▪ that picture? oh, i picked it up last week at a little shop downtown.

children.name: acquire b2
children.definition: acquire/əˈkwaɪəʳ/ formalto become the owner of something such as land, a company, or a valuable object:
examples: giành lại, chiếm
▪ in 1998 the business was acquired by a dutch company.
▪ the statue was acquired at great expense by the city corporation.
▪ robinson spent $20 million to acquire the symphony hall.
acquisition/ˌækwɪˈzɪʃən, ˌækwəˈzɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
acquisition of
▪ the national gallery has set aside £10 million for the acquisition of the painting.

children.name: go to shop to buy sth
go shopping a1
children.definition: go shopping/ˌgəʊ ˈʃɒpɪŋǁ-ˈʃɑː-/  to go to shops to look at and buy things:
examples: ▪ let’s meet in town. we can have lunch and go shopping.
▪ i’m going shopping now. do you want anything?

children.name: go to the shops u
children.definition: go to the shopsbritishgo to the storeamerican /ˌgəʊ tə ðə ˈʃɒps ǁ-ˈʃɑːps, ˌgəʊ tə ðə ˈstɔːʳ/  to go out to the local shop or shops in order to buy something, especially the things that you needregularlysuch as food:
examples: ▪ ‘where’s julie?’ ‘she’s gone to the shops.’
▪ if you go to the store, could you get some milk?
▪ mr parker, my next-door neighbour, is getting old and i sometimes go to the shops for him.

children.name: do the shopping a1
children.definition: do the shopping/ˌduː ðə ˈʃɒpɪŋǁ-ˈʃɑː-/  to go to shops in order to buy the things that you needregularlysuch as food:
examples: ▪ on saturdays we usually do the shopping and clean the house.
▪ she sent her husband out to do the week’s shopping.
do my/your etc shopping
▪ i did all my shopping yesterday.
grocery shoppingamerican shopping for food
▪ we need to go grocery shopping - do you have the check book?

children.name: shop b1
children.definition: shop/ʃɒpǁʃɑːp/  toregularlyuse aparticularshop, especially to buy things that you need regularly such as food:
examples: shop at/in
▪ i usually shop at safeway. it’s just around the corner from my house.
▪ when she moved here, she had never shopped in a supermarket before.
shopverb-pp-buy things
[ i ] to buythings in shopsmua hàng
_i like to shopatharrods for clothes.
_if i'm just shoppingforfood, i tend to go to the local supermarket.

children.name: shop around x
children.definition: shop around/ˌʃɒp əˈraʊndǁˌʃɑːp-/  to go toseveraldifferent shopscomparinggoods and theirpricesbefore deciding which ones to buy:
examples: ▪ if you shop around you could probably get the camera a lot cheaper.
shop around for
▪ i spent a couple of weeks shopping around for the lowest insurance rates.
shop aroundphrasal verb
to comparethe price and quality of the same or a similar
object in different shops before you decide which one to buy
_when you're buying a flight, you should always shop around for the best deal.
( .. ban nen di dao cac cua hang cho su thoa thuan tot nhat )

children.name: window shopping x
children.definition: window shopping/ˈwɪndəʊ ˌʃɒpɪŋǁ-ˌʃɑːp-/  when you look at things in shop windows without intending to buy anything:
examples: đi bát phố
▪ we spent the morning window shopping at all the antique stores.

children.name: to look at a lot of things you might buy, read, etc
look around b1
children.definition: lookaround to walk around a shop or market or a place wheretouristsgo, looking at a lot of different things: xem chung quanh
examples: he makes a list of what he needs and then walks into the store and buys it, without looking around at all.

children.name: browse b2
children.definition: browse to spend time looking at things in ashop, especiallybooksorrecords, without intending to buy anything:xem qua
examples: armando spent the afternoon browsing in camden market.
browse through
he found jill in the gallery shop silently browsing through some books.

children.name: i’m just looking x
children.definition: i’m just lookingsay this to tell sb who works in a shop that you are only looking at things, and you do not intend to buy anything just now:tôi chỉ xem chút thôi
examples: ‘can i help you?’ ‘no thanks, i’m just looking.’

children.name: window-shopping x
children.definition: window-shopping  the activity of looking at goods inshopwindowswithout intending to buy anything: dạo phố xem đồ
examples: we didn’t have any money but we enjoyed window-shopping in fifth avenue.
go window-shopping
sometimes i go window-shopping after work.

children.name: take a look around b1
children.definition: take/ have a look around to walk around a shop or market or a place wheretouristsgo, looking at a lot of different things: xem chung quanh
examples: i just want to take a quick look around and see if there’s anything i want.
you’re welcome to have a look around. we have a wide range of sportswear.

children.name: send out for x
children.definition: send out for/order out forus  to ask a restaurant or a food shop to deliver food to you at home or work: yêu cầu giao hàng
examples: during the meeting we sent out for some coffee.
i don’t feel like cooking tonight. let’s order out for a pizza.

children.name: order sth in x
children.definition: ordersthinphrasal verb đặt cái gì tại nhà
examples: to order foodthat is ready to eat to be brought to your home or to the place where you work
_i think i'll stay home tonight, order in a pizza and watch a video.

children.name: order a2
children.definition: ordernounrequest sự đặt hàng
examples: [ c ]a requestto make, supply ordeliverfood or goods
_"can itakeyour order now?" said the waiter.
_i would like toplace(= make) an order for a large pine table.

children.name: order a2
children.definition: order/ˈɔːʳdəʳ/  to ask for something you are going to pay for- use this about asking for food or drink in restaurants, or asking companies to send you goods:
examples: gọi món ăn
▪ would you like to order a drink before dinner?
▪ we had ordered a pale blue armchair but the one that was delivered was dark green.
▪ i’m afraid we don’t have that book in stock, but we can order it for you.
order[countable noun] đơn đặt hàng
▪ i’m very sorry, but we seem to have lost your order.
orderverbrequest gọi (món ăn, thức uống...),
[ i or t ] to ask for something to be made, supplied ordelivered, especially in a restaurant or shop
_i ordered some pasta and a mixed salad.
_[ + two objects ]there are no shirts left in this
size but we could order oneforyou/order you one.

children.name: place an order a2
children.definition: ordernounrequest sự đặt hàng
examples: [ c ]a requestto make, supply ordeliverfood or goods
_"can itakeyour order now?" said the waiter.
_i would like toplace(= make) an order for a large pine table.
( toi muon lam mot don dat hang cho mot ban go thong )
order formnoun[ c ] mẫu in sẵn để khách hàng đặt hàng điền vào; đơn đặt hàng
a printedform which a customer uses to request goods or a service
ordernounrequest hàng được đặt
[ c ] a product or a mealwhich has been requested by a customer
_the shop phoned to say your order has come in.

children.name: order x
children.definition: ordernounrequest hàng được đặt
examples: [ c ] a product or a mealwhich has been requested by a customer
_the shop phoned to say your order has come in.

children.name: order form x
children.definition: order formnoun mẫu in sẵn để khách hàng đặt hàng điền vào; đơn đặt hàng
examples: a printedform which a customer uses to request goods or a service

children.name: be on order x
children.definition: be on order ( da dat roi nhung chua nhan duoc )
examples: if something is on order, you have requested it but have not yet received it
_the new drilling equipment has been on order for several weeks.

children.name: to buy a lot of sth
buy a lot of a1
children.definition: buy a lot of/lots of/ˌbaɪ ə ˈlɒt ɒv, ˈlɒts ɒvǁ-ˈlɑːt-/
examples: ▪ you’ve been buying a lot of clothes recently. have you decided to change your image?
▪ we’ve bought lots of food and drink, so it should be a really good party.

children.name: stock up x
children.definition: stock up/ˌstɒk ˈʌpǁˌstɑːk-/  to buy alargequantityof something you useregularlybecause you may not be able to buy it later, or because you are planning to use more of it than usual:
examples: mua hàng ( nhiều để dự trữ )
▪ the supermarkets are full of people stocking up for the new year’s holiday.
▪ we might as well stock up while we’re here - it’ll save us having to come back.
stock up on
▪ we always stock up on cheap cigarettes when we go to holland.

children.name: buy (sth) in bulk a1c1
children.definition: buy (something) in bulk/ˌbaɪ something ɪn ˈbʌlk/  to buy a large quantity of something, especiallybecause it is cheaper to buy a lot of it at one time:
examples: mua số lượng lớn
▪ we always buy in bulk. it is so much more economical.
▪ today more shoppers are using coupons and buying items in bulk.
bulk buyingbuying goods in large quantities
▪ bulk buying has enabled the company to cut costs.

children.name: wholesale x
children.definition: wholesale/ˈhəʊlseɪl/  if you buy something wholesale, you buy a large quantity of it directly from the company that makes it:
examples: ( mua ) sỉ
▪ mark buys the earrings wholesale and then sells them for a profit.
▪ let’s see if we can get them wholesale and save ourselves a few dollars.
wholesale[adjective]
▪ the shopkeeper buys his fruit and vegetables at wholesale prices.

children.name: buy up x
children.definition: buy up/ˌbaɪ ˈʌp/  to quickly buy all of something such as land, tickets, food etc, when there is only a limited amount available:
examples: mua sạch, mua hết
buy up something
▪ in the last five years development agencies have bought up almost all the land in the area.
buy something up
▪ there weren’t any good seats left for the game - some big company had bought them all up.

children.name: buy in x
children.definition: buy in/ˌbaɪ ˈɪn/  british to buy enough of something to last for a long time, for example because it may be difficult to buy later:
examples: mua tích trữ
buy in something
▪ people had to buy in candles during the electricity strike.
buy something in
▪ villagers join together to buy enough food in to last throughout the winter.

children.name: import b2
children.definition: import/ɪmˈpɔːʳt/  to buy goods from another country to be sold, used etc in your country, especially in large quantities:
examples: nhập khẩu
▪ the united states has to import some of its oil.import something from something
▪ most of the wines served in this restaurant are imported from france.
imports/ˈɪmpɔːʳts/ [plural noun]hàng nhập
▪ in 1999 our imports goods that were imported greatly exceeded exports.
importverb[ t ]nhập, nhập khẩu
to buy or bring in products from another country
_we import a large number of carsfromjapan.

children.name: purchasing power x
children.definition: purchasing powernoun sức mua
examples: a person's purchasing power is their ability to buy goods
_the purchasing powerofpeople living on investmentincome has fallen as interest rates have gone down.

children.name: shopping a1
children.definition: shoppingnoun sự đi mua hàng
examples: the activityof buying things from shops
_the store is open for late night shopping on wednesdays.
_i'mgoingshopping this afternoon.
_my granddaughterdoesmy weekly shopping for me.
_christmasshopping

children.name: brand loyalty
children.definition: nounsự gắn bó với nhãn hiệu; sự trung thành với nhãn hiệu
examples: the habit always to buy a product with the same name, made by the same company
_all manufacturers want to encourage brand loyalty to their own products.

children.name: purchase b2
children.definition: purchasenounformalbuying vật mua được, vật tậu được
examples: [ c ] somethingthat you buy
_how do you wish to pay for your purchases?
_a major purchase ( hang lon )

children.name: purchase b2
children.definition: purchasenounformalbuying sự mua
examples: [ c or u ]the actof buying something
_new restrictions have been placed on the purchaseofguns.
_a house is the most expensive purchase that most people evermake.
_no purchase is necessary for you to enter this competition.
_this product may be frozen. if required, freeze on day of purchase.

children.name: import c1
children.definition: importnounbringing in hàng nhập, hàng nhập khẩu
examples: [ c ] goodsbought by one country from another
_restrictions on foreign imports ( han che hang nhap khau nuoc ngoai )

children.name: import /importation c2
children.definition: importnounbringing in sự nhập, sự nhập khẩu
examples: [ u ] (alsoimportation)the actionof bringing goods or fashions into a country
_the illegal importation of drugs
_an import licence ( mot su cho fep nhap khau )
_import duties ( thue nhap khau )

children.name: on approval
children.definition: được bán với điều kiện khách không vừa ý thì cứ trả lại
examples: if you buysomethingon approval, you can return it without payment if it is not satisfactory.
